Well I think Cornell misses the point of preambles. Cornell appears to me to have started his research by first drawing a conclusion and then going off to wade through the available material in a search for things which might support his conclusion. It is a little like showing up at a very crowded cocktail party, and as soon as you come through the door standing up on your toes to look over the heads of all the guests there in search for your friends. 
 
 By looking over the crowd for his friends, I believe he ignores the fact that preambles were widely used in all of the constitutions of the time, and that in every case they were intended to introduce the right referenced by first stating a universally held truth or belief. There is not a single instance I can find where a preamble was designed to limit the right which follows it, and it is only where the RKBA is concerned that anyone, like Cornell, for example, even attempts to use the preamble as a noose to restrict the right. 
 
 There are many examples of the use of preambles Cornell ignores which I could cite, all of which pre-date the drafting of the 2nd. Amendment. Here is one from the Constitution of Massachusetts:
 
 "The liberty of the press is essential to the security of freedom in a state: it ought not, therefore, to be restrained in this Commonwealth." 
 
 Here is another example, which comes from the constitution of my beloved Commonwealth of Virginia:
 
 "That religion, or the duty which we owe to our Creator, and the manner of discharging it, can be directed only by reason and conviction, not by force or violence; and therefore all men are equally entitled to the free exercise of religion, according to the dictates of conscience; and that it is the mutual duty of all to practice Christian forbearance, love, and charity towards each other." 
 
 In each of these we see that the right is introduced by first stating a universally held belief, and these preambles cannot be construed as somehow limiting the right they introduce.
 
 I would challenge Cornell to find a single instance where a preamble can be shown as intended to modify or constrict the substantive right.
 
 Cornell obviously would say the Second Amendment's preamble is one, but again I think he misses the point of that preamble. This is what he said of the preamble [in the article cited, which is in response to then AG Ashcroft's 2001 letter setting forth an individual RKBA interpretation of the 2nd. Amendment]:
 
 "The Department of Justice has thus erased the preamble, which states the purpose of the amendment, to create a 'well regulated Militia.'"
 http://www.h-net.org/~hns/articles/2005/012305a.html. 
 
 If we assume Cornell is right, then the natural question is did the founders enshrine this purpose in the Constitution and then forget about it? Where is this militia the amendment was supposed to create? The answer is it does not exist, because that was not the purpose of the amendment. The militia system pre-existed the amendment, and was not modified in any way by the adoption of the amendment.
 
 But another and more damning question Cornell fails to address is why the preamble states "of a free state"? He cannot answer this question, because if he is right-if the preamble is not merely stating a universal truth, but was instead designed to limit the RKBA to the creation of a militia-then the inclusion of the words "free state" becomes an exercise in writing mere wasteful surplussage.
 
 Here again is the Second Amendment preamble:
 
 "A well regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state."
 
 In my opinion, this was not intended to create a militia which the founders then later decided to ignore in favor of a standing army. Rather, its intended effect was to enshrine within the Constitution the following truth: 
 
 "It has been asserted by the most respectable writers upon government, that a well-regulated militia, composed of the yeomanry of the country, have ever been considered as the bulwark of a free people. Tyrants have never placed any confidence on a militia composed of freemen." John DeWitt, The Anti-Federalist Papers, p. 75 (M. Borden ed. 1965)
 
 This is why the preamble reads "free" state-that is, a state where citizens do not live in fear of a tyrant using a standing army to oppress them. And If you look, you will see where Madison got his inspiration for including this truth, because it had been expressed in some form or other within a preamble in every state constitution of the time. Here are some examples:
 
 CONSTITUTION OF VIRGINIA (June 6, 1776)
 
 "That a well-regulated militia, composed of the body of the people, trained to arms, is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a free state; that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty; and that in all cases the military should be under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power."
 
 CONSTITUTION OF NEW HAMPSHIRE (June 2, 1784)
 
 "A well-regulated militia is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a state.
 
 Standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up without the consent of the legislature."
 
 CONSTITUTION OF MARYLAND (November 3, 1776) 
 
 "That a well-regulated militia is the proper and natural defense of a free government.
 
 That standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up, without consent of the legislature."
 
 DELAWARE DECLARATION OF RIGHTS (September 11, 1776) 
 
 "That a well-regulated militia is the proper, natural and safe defense of a free government.
 
 That standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up without the consent of the legislature."
 
 This, in my opinion, is where Madison found and copied his second amendment preamble belief. Therefore, I read the language "[a] well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free State" as never being intended by our founding fathers to limit the right of the people to keep and bear private arms. Rather, it is a simple preamble which states the universally held principle that "standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty."
 
 And (with Madison's blessing) this was exactly how the amendment was sold to the public for ratification:
 
 "As civil rulers, not having their duty to the people duly before them, may attempt to tyrannize, and as the military forces which must be occasionally raised to defend our country, might pervert their power to the injury of their fellow citizens, the people are confirmed by the article in their right to keep and bear private arms." Tench Coxe, Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution. Published under the pseudonym, "A Pennsylvanian" in the Philadelphia Federal Gazette, June 18, 1789 at 2 Col. 1.
 
 Why, then was it included within the Second Amendment along with the RKBA? First, because it was an important enough statement to be included within the Constitution. Second, it naturally fits in this amendment because the individual RKBA which follows it was and is the counterweight to a government which abandons the truth expressed in the preamble-a government which relies too heavily upon a standing army only to have a tyrant seize control of it to use as a tool of oppression:
 
 "Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed; as they are in almost every kingdom of Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior to any bands of regular troops that can be, on any pretense, raised in the United States. A military force, at the command of Congress, can execute no laws, but such as the people perceive to be just and constitutional; for they will possess the power, and jealousy will instantly inspire the inclination, to resist the execution of a law which appears to them unjust and oppressive." Noah Webster, "An Examination into the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution" (1787) in Pamphlets on the Constitution of the United States (P. Ford, 1888).
 
 Therefore, I submit this is a far more logical interpretation of the militia preamble than Cornell's strained interpretation, and I believe it better tracks the following advice given by Thomas Jefferson:
 
 "On every question of construction let us carry ourselves back to the time when the Constitution was adopted, recollect the spirit manifested in the debates, and instead of trying what meaning can be squeezed out of the text, or invented against it, conform to the probable one which was passed." I want to add my two cents on Lewis v. U.S. since it has been addressed in this thread. Although Lewis briefly addressed the 2nd Amendment in a footnote, it was not a 2nd Amendment case. It was a 5th/14th Amendment due process/equal protection case. Lewis had been convicted in Florida of a felony in 1961. At that trial, he was denied his right to counsel, and was therefore convicted in a trial that happened without the benefit of a lawyer to represent him. Two years after his conviction, SCOTUS decided the case of Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335 (1963), in which it held that state felony convictions like Lewis' violate the 6th. Amendment. When Lewis was later caught with a gun in Virginia and prosecuted federally as a felon in possession, the government used his old 1961 conviction to prove his disabled status as a felon. On appeal to SCOTUS, Lewis attempted to collaterally attack his old felony conviction. He claimed that using the un-counseled felony conviction against him violated his 5th/14th Amendment due process/equal protection right. SCOTUS deals with all claims involving equal protection/due process by using the "rational relation" test to see if the statute was unconstitutional, and you will see that test used here. Here is the full text of part IV of the Lewis opinion, in which SCOTUS makes a passing reference to the 2nd Amendment in footnote 8: 
 
 LEWIS v. U.S., 445 U.S. 55, 65-68 (1980) 
 
 "The firearm regulatory scheme at issue here is consonant with the concept of equal protection embodied in the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment if there is "some 'rational basis' for the statutory distinctions made . . . or . . . they 'have some relevance to the purpose for which the classification is made.'" Marshall v. United States, 414 U.S. 417, 422 (1974), quoting from McGinnis v. Royster, 410 U.S. 263, 270 (1973), and Baxstrom v. Herold, 383 U.S. 107, 111 (1966). See Vance v. Bradley, 440 U.S. 93, 97 (1979). [FOOTNOTE 8, SEE BELOW] [Page 66]
 
 Section 1202 (a)(1) clearly meets that test. Congress, as its expressed purpose in enacting Title VII reveals, 18 U.S.C. App. § 1201, was concerned that the receipt and possession of a firearm by a felon constitutes a threat, among other things, to the continued and effective operation of the Government of the United States. The legislative history of the gun control laws discloses Congress' worry about the easy availability of firearms, especially to those persons who pose a threat to community peace. And Congress focused on the nexus between violent crime and the possession of a firearm by any person with a criminal record. 114 Cong. Rec. 13220 (1968) (remarks of Sen. Tydings); id., at 16298 (remarks of Rep. Pollock). Congress could rationally conclude that any felony conviction, even an allegedly invalid one, is a sufficient basis on which to prohibit the possession of a firearm. See, e.g., United States v. Ransom, 515 F.2d 885, 891-892 (CA5 1975), cert. denied, 424 U.S. 944 (1976). This Court has recognized repeatedly that a legislature constitutionally may prohibit a convicted felon from engaging in activities far more fundamental than the possession of a firearm. See Richardson v. Ramirez, 418 U.S. 24 (1974) (disenfranchisement); De Veau v. Braisted, 363 U.S. 144 (1960) (proscription against holding office in a waterfront labor organization); Hawker v. New York, 170 U.S. 189 (1898) (prohibition against the practice of medicine).
 
 We recognize, of course, that under the Sixth Amendment an uncounseled felony conviction cannot be used for certain purposes. See Burgett, Tucker, and Loper, all supra. The Court, however, has never suggested that an uncounseled conviction [Page 67] is invalid for all purposes. See Scott v. Illinois, 440 U.S. 367 (1979); Loper v. Beto, 405 U.S., at 482. n. 11 (plurality opinion).
 
 Use of an uncounseled felony conviction as the basis for imposing a civil firearms disability, enforceable by a criminal sanction, is not inconsistent with Burgett, Tucker, and Loper. In each of those cases, this Court found that the subsequent conviction of sentence violated the Sixth Amendment because it depended upon the reliability of a past uncounseled conviction. The federal gun laws, however, focus not on reliability, but on the mere fact of conviction, or even indictment, in order to keep firearms away from potentially dangerous persons. Congress' judgment that a convicted felon. even one whose conviction was allegedly uncounseled, is among the class of persons who should be disabled from dealing in or possessing firearms because of potential dangerousness is rational.9 Enforcement of that essentially civil disability through a criminal sanction does not "support guilt or enhance punishment." see Burgett, 389 U.S., at 115, on the basis of a conviction that is unreliable when one considers Congress' broad purpose. Moreover, unlike the situation in Burgett, the sanction imposed by § 1202 (a)(1) attaches immediately upon the defendant's first conviction.
 
 Again, it is important to note that a convicted felon may challenge the validity of a prior conviction. or otherwise remove his disability, before obtaining a firearm. We simply hold today that the firearms prosecution does not open the predicate conviction to a new form of collateral attack. See Note, Prior Convictions and the Gun Control Act of 1968. [Page 68] 76 Colum. L. Rev. 326, 338-339 (1976). Cf. Walker v. City of Birmingham, 388 U.S. 307 (1967)."
 
 [FOOTNOTE 8] "These legislative restrictions on the use of firearms are neither based upon constitutionally suspect criteria, nor do they trench upon any constitutionally protected liberties. See United States v. Miller, 307 U.S. 174, 178 (1939) (the Second Amendment guarantees no right to keep and bear a firearm that does not have "some reasonable relationship to the preservation or efficiency of a well regulated militia"); United States v. Three Winchester 30-30 Caliber Lever Action Carbines, 504 F.2d 1288, 1290, n. 5 (CA7 1974); United States v. Johnson, 497 F.2d 548 (CA4 1974); Cody v. United States, 460 F.2d 34 (CA8), cert. denied, 409 U.S. 1010 (1972) (the latter three cases holding, respectively, that § 1202 (a)(1), § 922 (g), and § 922 (a)(6) do not violate the Second Amendment)."
 
 The interesting thing about this case is SCOTUS assumed Lewis had standing to raise a 2nd. Amendment claim. Before you can ever challenge a statute on the grounds that it violates a constitutional right, you must first show that you had standing to claim protection from the right-that is, you must first show that you are a person or entity whom the right applies to. For example, if the 2nd. Amendment RKBA was a right only of the states to arm their militias, then only a state could come before SCOTUS and complain that it was denied the right. 
 
 Now George Calvin Lewis, Jr. is obviously not a state. He never claimed to be a member of any state militia, and he never claimed that the firearm he possessed was kept for any purpose other than an individual one. If SCOTUS was prepared to adopt the collective right view of the 2nd. Amendment, then it would have dismissed Lewis' claim to 2nd Amendment protection out of hand for lack of standing. It would have said that since the right does not apply to individual citizens he could not complain that he was being denied the right. In short, you can't claim to be protected by a right you never had to begin with.
 
 For 2nd. Amendment analysis purposes, what SCOTUS did in Lewis was assume that an individual citizen who possesses a firearm for an individual purpose can claim the protection of a 2nd Amendment individual RKBA-and then it ruled that a ban on felons possessing firearms is a restriction which does not unconstitutionally infringe upon that individual right. I think it is easy to justify how a felon in possession ban can be reconciled with an individual RKBA, but SCOTUS' limited treatment of the subject does not explain its justification for this. Instead of giving the subject the treatment it deserved, SCOTUS merely regurgitated the flawed analysis in Miller (which was NOT a felon in possession case) without explaining how the holding in Miller applies to the facts in this case.

Neither is it in any manner dependent upon that instrument for its existence. The second amendment declares that it shall not be infringed; but this, as has been seen, means no more than it shall not be infringed by Congress.  1. Whether we think judges engage in so-called "judicial activism" or not, one key restraint on the power of the federal judiciary has always been the Article III Section 2 requirement that federal courts avoid overstepping their authority by accepting and deciding cases that do not present a "case or controversy." This principle which sets the scope of judicial authority is fundamental that SCOTUS never ignores it. The following cases illustrate how important this point is:
 
 Under Article III, § 2, of the Constitution, the federal courts have jurisdiction over this dispute between appellants and appellees only if it is a "case" or "controversy." This is a "bedrock requirement." Valley Forge Christian College v. Americans United for Separation of Church and State, Inc., 454 U.S. 464, 471 (1982). As we said in Simon v. Eastern Ky. Welfare Rights Organization, 426 U.S. 26, 37 (1976): "No principle is more fundamental to the judiciary's proper role in our system of government than the constitutional limitation of federal-court jurisdiction to actual cases or controversies. One element of the case-or-controversy requirement is that appellees, based on their complaint, must establish that they have standing to sue. Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 561 (1992).Raines v. Byrd, 521 U.S. 811, 818 (1997)
 
 Standing is the "irreducible constitutional minimum" necessary to make a justiciable "case" or "controversy" under Article III, § 2. Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560. Steel Co. v. Citizens for Better Environment, 523 U.S. 83, 84 (1998)
 
 Now without this limitation on the federal judiciary, there is nothing to prevent SCOTUS from interjecting itself into any public policy debate it wants to at any time. This unbridled power has always been rejected by SCOTUS, and to avoid treading into such dangerous ground standing is something that the Court always looks to. In these cases the law permits us to assume standing exists. In any case where standing is even remotely questionable, however, SCOTUS always deals with that issue on the record in its opinion, and only after it agrees that standing exists will it then rule on the questions presented in the case. The best example I can give you of this process was Roe v. Wade, where the Court struggled with the idea of finding standing for the female plaintiff who at the time the case came before SCOTUS was no longer pregnant. Now SCOTUS clearly wanted to reach and rule on the issue of abortion, but it could not ignore the standing issue to do so. Pregnancy provides a classic justification for a conclusion of nonmootness. It truly could be "capable of repetition, yet evading review." Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113, 125 (1973). 
 
 The constitutional point I think Cornell misses is standing is such a fundamental concept that no matter how badly SCOTUS wants to get its hands on an issue, no matter how necessary it feels the need to be to rule on the merits of a case issue, it never ignores or runs roughshod over the question of standing to reach the substance of the case.

Amendment claim for lack of standing but did not do so because "the Supreme Court wanted to make it clear that Congress' regulation of such guns was Constitutional." Here, the use of the word "persons" merely confirms that the phrase "the people" also refers to individuals. 
 
 But Amar still will not let the collective definition go: "Why, then, did the Fourth use the words "the people" at all?" Here is where I believe Amar overreaches the most: 
 
 "Probably to highlight the role that jurors--acting collectively and representing the electorate--would play in deciding which searches were reasonable and how much to punish government officials who searched or seized improperly." 
 
 Again, there is no analysis of this argument. He cites no example, no statement, no court precedent or procedure to support this guesswork. This is because none exists. I have been immersed in the 4th. Amendment for over 15 years now. I deal with it on a near daily basis. In our criminal justice system, juries never have, and never did, play any role in deciding which searches or seizures violated the 4th. Amendment. These are always questions of law decided in hearings and arguments before judges. On the civil side of the law, individuals (because the phrase "the people" refers to individuals) can sue the government and have government officials punished financially for violations of their 4th. Amendment right. I doubt, however, that this is what Madison was referring to. The ability to file such a lawsuit did not exist until Congress passed legislation permitting it in 1979 (42 U.S.C. 1983). If we argue that Madison would have used the phrase "the people" to refer to jury vindication of a violation of a civil right, when juries were neither intended nor permitted to do so by any of his amendments, and in fact could not do so until authorized by congressional statute 200 years later, then we suggest that Madison should have a far greater reputation for prescience than Nostradamus. 
 
 Amar completely fails to link such an oblique speculation. His only argument in favor of his guess (for that is all it is) is to point to an earlier, rejected draft of the 6th. Amendment right to trial by jury-chosen, presumably, because it contains the phrase "as one of the best securities to the rights of the people, ought to remain inviolate." No where in this cited example does Madison state or even remotely suggest that juries should act collectively to protect the right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure (nor does this imputation exist in the adopted 4th. Amendment). 
 
 Use of this example does, ironically, support the individual right view. It is yet another example of Madison's penchant for including universally believed statements in the amendments he was drafting. These statements of principle, like the 2nd. Amendment militia preamble, have no impact on the right itself. They merely state one (of many) public rationales for the importance of protecting the right. The phrase quoted by Amar does not limit the 4th. Amendment right at all, it merely states that the right was viewed important enough to be included in his Bill of Rights (because it is one of the "best securities" of the rights of the people). The same is true of the militia preamble, which informs us that standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and that to secure a "free" state we should rely instead upon a militia. As I have argued before, there are many examples of Madison and other draftsmen of his time including these goals or principles with the substantive right. It is only with the RKBA that anyone seems encouraged to argue a statement of principle should be used as a rope to strangle the right it accompanies.
